description.narrative:
Den afrikanska "Children's Charter" antogs 1999 av AU:s medlemsstater och har sedan dess ratificerats av 47 av AU:s 54 medlemsstater. 2001 etablerades en expertkommitte med uppgift att följa upp medlemsstaternas åtagande och granska rapportering. Expertkommittén har dessvärre inte kunnat uppfylla sitt mandat på ett adekat sätt, framför allt pga bristande resurser.
Det här projektet är en fortsättning på tidigare avtal. Det syftar till att ge teknisk assistans till expertkommittén för att på så sätt stärka upp uppföljningen av Children's Charter.
Erfarenheter från tidigare projektperiod är goda. Ambassadens avtalspart, Plan Sweden, har uppfyllt sina åtaganden och resultaten har varit i linje med plan.

The African Children's Charter was adopted by the AU Member States in 1999 and has since been ratified by 47 of the AU 54 Member States. In 2001, an expert committee was set up to monitor the Member States' commitment and review reports. Unfortunately, the Expert Committee has not been able to fulfill its mandate adequately, in particular due to lack of resources.
This project is a continuation of previous agreements. It aims to provide technical assistance to the Expert Committee in order to strengthen the follow-up of the Children's Charter.
To facilitate the promotion and implementation of the ACRWC through a strengthened ACERWC; and increased engagement of African civil society organizations with the ACERWC.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: This bridging phase project was initiated as a short-term support to keep the momentum and consolidate the gains from the previous phase before a long term new phase. In line with this, the project helped to improve the capacity of the African Committee of Experts on the Right and Welfare of the Child (ACERWC) to implement its mandate through, among others, the provision of increased human and financial capacity to its Secretariat. Accordingly, the project contributed towards increased budgetary allocation for the Committee through the project’s support for the participation of the Committee during the PRC Executive Council to defend its budget. As a result, the Committee’s budget was noted to have grown from USD 400,000 by the end of phase 1 to USD 738,990 in 2016 and to USD 827,557 in 2017. Owing to its improved capacity, the Committee was able to review an increasing number of State Party Reports and Concluding Observations. It has developed documents for the interpretation of selected themes and articles of the African Charter on the Rights and Welfare of the Child (ACERWC), including a Concept Note to the Day of the African Child (DAC), and the third General Comment on the Responsibilities of the Child (Article 31 of the ACRWC), and a joint General Comments with the African Commission on Human and Peoples’ Rights in relation to article 6 (b) of the Maputo Protocol and article 21(2) of the ACRWC. Increased capacity of the ACERWC was also supported by the development of Agenda 2040, Africa’s Agenda for children: Fostering an Africa Fit for Children, which was adopted by the ACERWC during its 28th Ordinary Session. The adoption of the long-term agenda reflects the strengthened capacity of the ACERWC. The ACERWC´s promotional mandate is enhanced through the support for remuneration for the Communication Officer, and despite the fact that there was no concurrent budget for the implementation of the Communication Plan. The Consortium, however, supported efforts to seek funds for the activities. The evaluation of the programme showed that the implementation of the Communication Plan had contributed to the increased visibility of the Committee and its work. The updated website substantially contributed to this result. The project further enabled the ACERWC to pursue initiatives with AU policy organs and ECOWAS to integrate the African Charter on the Rights and Welfare of the Child in a more systematic way in their operations. The project has also contributed to the ACERWC and child rights CSOs efforts to collaborate more efficiently and strategically with RECs such as ECOWAS to promote and implement the Charter.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
